body: I don't. Jenkins UI takes forever to load right now, I suspect test infrastructure is not doing well.
There was a lint complaint. I created this change in the UI and did not notice some line exceeded 80 characters.
@herohde would you be willing to review this PR?
R: @lukecwik for merge (Ahmet is on vacation)
Jenkins job is stuck due to Dataflow runner. Let me take a look.
I am working on fixing the shadow plugin configuration in the gradle build
LGTM, waiting on tests, will merge after.
should we not sync the gradle build?

compilation times of module sql with and without incremental build are similar around 8s. So I guess deactivating it as a defensive measure is a good thing. Besides Jenkins fails on workcounts which is not related to this PR I think. LGTM, but I wonder if all PRs should update gradle build as soon as the change maven build.

I suppose we should update the gradle build in every case, however the gradle build does not break because of this issue (at least in my tests) so I don't think it needs to be updated. Thanks for the review.
Sorry to been late on this one. It looks good to me.
I simplified the test using `withMaxReadTime()` as suggested. I also did a rebase.
rebased, updated the gradle build config
Does this allow us to remove any POM/gradle dependencies between projects?

No, the import statements were referencing components of the core.

It does serve as an existence proof that the code in the testing package could be split off into its own package so that the "core" package wouldn't have testing code inside it.
Any idea what the failure of file-based IO IT is ? Seems to be unrelated to this PR but we should investigate.
Ups. Accidentally messed up this branch. I'll resend the PR and address the comment.

If I understand correctly, we may want to make different choices about generating bytecode (and how to do it) versus cached reflection (and how to do this) so the best thing to do would be to put the interface in a place that allows us to do each of these things and compare their performance. We can then change our mind over time.

Is there something in the API that would be a problem for this?
LGTM. Seems like this shell step could be factored out somewhere, but I'll leave off insisting on refactors.
The maven build failed on WordCount https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3397 but succeeded otherwise.

the jenkins build is stuck on wordcount tests on dataflow runner. I tested the build locally but it fails on `runners.core.construction.ArtifactServiceStagerTest`  and `sdk.io.kinesis.KinesisMockReadTest` which are known flaky tests and are unrelated to this PR. The nexmark module build passes. So I think we can merge this PR
Nice! I'll take a look. Have patience with my review - it is a pretty big PR :-)
I just updated KinesisReaderIT because the test was disabled and fixed some dep problem to finally run it with success, Thanks for suggesting this. PTAL @lukecwik

Is it guaranteed that split() is always called before BigtableReader's splitAtFraction()? If so, then yes we can produce single-range sources so that we don't need a multi-range tracker. Otherwise, splitAtFraction() would break if the BigtableReader's source was multi-range.

Yes, sources are always split before being read.

On Wed, Jan 3, 2018, 12:25 PM rniemo-g <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Is it guaranteed that split() is always called before BigtableReader's
> splitAtFraction()? If so, then yes we can produce single-range sources so
> that we don't need a multi-range tracker. Otherwise, splitAtFraction()
> would break if the BigtableReader's source was multi-range.
>

Thanks for the explanation and sorry for the delay - got a family situation that leaves me in reduced capacity for the next few weeks. I'll get to this in the next couple of days.

Can you take a look at this test failure: https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_Java_GradleBuild/794/testReport/junit/org.apache.beam.sdk.io.kinesis/KinesisReaderTest/watermarkAdvancesWhenEnoughRecordsReadRecently/
What's the next action on this PR? Does BEAM-3344 need to be fixed before this PR can proceed, or does that issue merely expose a symptom of a different problem? If so, do we know how to fix it?
ValidatesRunner tests passed back then, but now this needs to be rebased. I think if after rebase tests pass again, then we can merge this. @mairbek could you rebase?

BEAM-3344 exposed a different problem and is a pretty easy fix to for serialization/deserialization of pipeline options before execution. Fixing BEAM-3344 does not block this change nor does this change block fixing BEAM-3344.

The next steps on this PR is for a couple of implementations of common `AwsCredentialsProvider` Jackson serialization modules so that the credential provider can be sent to workers for Flink/Spark/Dataflow/...

Review status: 0 of 3 files reviewed at latest revision, 3 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed. --- *[sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/testing/TestStream.java, line 145 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4301#-L0ufMEoIcWoRoRBCg74-r1-145:-L1y40oUfmJJk8HToIhz:b-ago5t) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/f1bd748cd47c2a1bf5245e2d4913d043cf0d4925/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/testing/TestStream.java#L145)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
This change is useful for getting quiescence without advancing the watermark, yes? I think it is worth an explicit mention in the javadoc and/or some syntactic sugar like `quiesce()`.
Actually I changed this simply so that you could call advanceWatermarkTo() with the same value twice in a row, changing a ">" to ">=", because timestamps generated in WaitTest may after rounding become only non-strictly monotonic, and I think it should be allowed. --- *[sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/transforms/Wait.java, line 33 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4301#-L0ufMEpVUjntlqj21ME-r2-33:-L1yAUy1WX3EulYCxP9N:b-896fix) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/f7ea3853137d4b6fc908c95dfb443907983c43d4/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/transforms/Wait.java#L33)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
This one-liner seems a bit misleading. What does it mean to be ready? I think the details make it clear, but the summary line should be more technically rigorous. And the phrasing "allows ..." is usually redundant with just an active rephrasing. Perhaps something like > Delays processing of each window in a PCollection until signaled. > > Given a main PCollection and a signal PCollection, produces output identical to its main input but all elements for a window are produced only once that window is closed in the signal PCollection".
Done. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4301)*

I've left a protobuf round-trip in this change to ensure that all tests pass on rehydrated pipelines. I can remove this before submitting.

I've left a few TODOs inline as questions to the reviewer.

Finally, I'm not sure stylistically if it's appropriate to use these try-catch blocks everywhere.  How is this normally handled in Beam? Should I bother with better error messages?
Rebased and updated according to the comments.
Thanks. Updated commit message and PR description to include both fixes.
What's the word on this? https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/4078 ?
@sneurlax Python 3 conversion work is ongoing. The master issue for tracking is: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-1251. If you are interested, we would be happy to accept contributions.
Parameterized the Jenkins job ... @lukecwik can you take a look?
Thanks. The fn_api_runner stuff is mostly refactoring.

Perform the same change in the gradle build file.

Note that updating bumps up the version numbers for gRPC and protobuf. Other then the bigtable version bump, did any of the transitive dependencies version change?
We do need to stick with Java 7 until the vote concludes. But this PR could perhaps wait for that result rather than reverting.
What should we do about this PR ? Should I remove the rat configuration to relay on `.gitignore` ?
Obviously only the `BEAM-2140` commits are part of this but when I opened the PR some other stuff was still in there because the GitHub sync seems a bit slow.
